{{Infobox scientist |name = Lawrence Johnston |image = |image_size = |caption = Lawrence Johnston |birth_date = {{birth date|1918|2|11}} |birth_place = [[Shandong]], [[China]] |death_date = {{death date and age|mf=y|2011|12|4|1918|2|11}} |death_place = [[Moscow, Idaho]] |residence = Moscow, Idaho |citizenship = |nationality = American |ethnicity = |alma_mater = [[University of California, Berkeley]],
B.S. 1940, Ph.D. 1950 |field = [[Physics]] |work_institutions = [[Los Alamos Laboratory]]
[[University of Minnesota]]
[[The Aerospace Corporation]]
[[Stanford Linear Accelerator Center]]
[[University of Idaho]] |doctoral_advisor = [[Luis Walter Alvarez]] |doctoral_students = |known_for = |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |prizes = |religion = |footnotes = |signature = |spouse = Mildred (Millie) Hillis Johnston |children = 1 son, 4 daughters }} '''Lawrence Harding''' "'''Larry'''" '''Johnston''' (February 11, 1918 – December 4, 2011) was an American physicist, a young contributor to the [[Manhattan Project]]. He was the only man to witness all three atomic explosions in 1945: the [[Trinity nuclear test]] and the [[atomic bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki]].{{cite news |url=http://missoulian.com/lifestyles/territory/idaho-man-witness-to-atomic-blasts/article_994031d6-121a-11e1-8663-001cc4c03286.html |newspaper=Missoulian |location=Montana |agency=''(Lewiston Tribune)'' |title=Idaho man witness to 3 atomic blasts |last=Lee |first=Sandra L. Lee |date=November 19, 2011 |accessdate=October 18, 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://pullmanmoscow.kxly.com/news/people/67313-former-colleagues-remember-manhattan-project-scientist |publisher=Pullman-Moscow News |agency=(KXLY Spokane) |title=Former colleagues remember Manhattan Project scientist |last=Hensley |first=Nicole |date=December 6, 2011 |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141025075639/http://pullmanmoscow.kxly.com/news/people/67313-former-colleagues-remember-manhattan-project-scientist |archivedate=October 25, 2014 |df= }} During [[World War II]], he worked at the [[MIT Radiation Laboratory]] where he invented [[ground-controlled approach]] radar. In 1944, he went to the Manhattan Project's [[Los Alamos Laboratory]], where he co-invented the [[exploding-bridgewire detonator]]. After the war he completed his [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] thesis in 1950, and became an associate professor at the [[University of Minnesota]] in [[Minneapolis]]. He later worked at the [[Stanford Linear Accelerator Center]] as head of the electronics department, and was a professor at the [[University of Idaho]] in [[Moscow, Idaho|Moscow]],{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=M6hYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=r_gDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3860%2C1610666 |newspaper=Spokane Daily Chronicle |title=UI professors change rank |date=July 7, 1971 |page=b3 }}{{cite web|url=http://issuu.com/uidahodigital/docs/gem1983/111 |work=Gem of the Mountains |agency=(University of Idaho yearbook) |title=Idaho's lifeblood: research |year=1983 |page=106}} where he taught until his retirement. ==Early life== Born in [[Shandong]], [[China]], on February 11, 1918,{{cite web |url=http://sfcompanion.blogspot.com/2014/02/inventor-atomic-bomb-witness-and.html |work=South Fork Companion |date=February 11, 2013 |title=Inventor, Atomic Bomb Witness, and University Professor Larry Johnston |accessdate=October 18, 2014 }} Johnston's parents were American [[Presbyterian]] missionaries.{{cite web |url=http://www2.asa3.org/archive/asa/200208/0005.html |last=Johnston |first=Lawrence |title=Bio: Lawrence Johnston |publisher=[[American Scientific Affiliation]] |accessdate=August 31, 2013 }} The family returned to the United States in 1923, and his father became a Presbyterian pastor in [[Santa Maria, California]]. After graduation from [[Hollywood High School]] in 1936, Johnston earned an [[associate degree]] at [[Los Angeles City College]]. He transferred to the [[University of California, Berkeley|University of California]] in [[Berkeley, California|Berkeley]], where [[Luis Walter Alvarez]] was a graduate student. Johnston received his [[bachelor's degree]] in physics in 1940.{{cite web |url=http://www.webpages.uidaho.edu/~johnston/VITA.doc |title=Vita for Lawrence Johnston |publisher=University of Idaho |date=October 28, 2010 |accessdate=October 18, 2014}}{{cite news |url=http://www.ieeeghn.org/wiki/index.php/Oral-History:Lawrence_Johnston |publisher=IEEE Global History Network |title=Oral-History: Lawrence Johnston |last=Nebeker |first=Frederik |agency=(interview) |date=June 13, 1991 |accessdate=October 18, 2014}} ==World War II== ===MIT Radiation Laboratory=== Johnston intended to study for his [[Doctor of Philosophy|doctorate]] under Alvarez, but instead followed him east to the [[MIT Radiation Laboratory]] near [[Boston]] in February 1941. Alvarez and Johnston worked together on [[ground-controlled approach]] radar. This allowed aircraft to be guided a safe landing in adverse weather conditions, based on radar images, and would later prove crucial during the [[Berlin Airlift]].{{cite news |newspaper=[[Moscow-Pullman Daily News]] |url=http://dnews.com/obituaries/article_638dd0a7-0065-51db-b6ac-08563d7abe78.html?mode=story |title=Obituary:Lawrence H. 'Larry' Johnston, 93, Moscow |accessdate=August 31, 2013 }} They were awarded US Patents 2,555,101 and 2,585,855 for it. While a graduate student at Berkeley, Johnston met Mildred (Millie) Hillis, a girl who shared his strong Christian faith. When Alvarez discovered how much Johnston missed Hillis, he arranged for Johnston to be flown back to Berkeley. Johnston and Hillis married, and returned to Boston together. She sometimes accompanied them on field trips to test the ground-controlled approach radar system. They had five children: Mary Virginia (Ginger), Margy, Dan, Lois, and Karen. ===Manhattan Project=== [[File:Lawrence Johnston with Fat man core.jpg|thumb|right|240px|Johnston with the [[Fat Man]] [[plutonium core]] on [[Tinian]] in 1945]] In 1944, Johnston followed Alvarez to the [[Manhattan Project]]'s [[Los Alamos Laboratory]], where [[Robert Oppenheimer]], who was also from the University of California, was the director. Johnston became involved in the development of the [[Fat Man]] [[plutonium]] bomb. Because of the high level of [[spontaneous fission]] in reactor plutonium, it was decided to use a nearly critical sphere of the metal and compress it quickly into a much smaller and denser [[plutonium core|core]] using explosives, a technical challenge at the time.{{sfn|Alvarez|1987|pp=123–128}} To create the symmetrical [[nuclear weapon design|implosion]] required to compress the plutonium to the required density, thirty-two explosive charges were simultaneously detonated around the spherical core. Using conventional explosive techniques with [[blasting cap]]s, progress towards achieving simultaneity to within a small fraction of a microsecond was discouraging. Alvarez directed Johnston to use a large [[capacitor]] to deliver a [[high voltage]] charge directly to each [[explosive lens]], replacing blasting caps with [[exploding-bridgewire detonator]]s. This detonated all thirty-two charges within a few tenths of a microsecond. The invention was critical to the success of the [[implosion-type nuclear weapon]].{{sfn|Alvarez|1987|pp=131–136}} Johnston was awarded US Patent 3,040,660 for the exploding-bridgewire detonator. Johnston and Alvarez's next task for the Manhattan Project was to develop a set of calibrated [[microphone]]/[[transmitter]]s to be parachuted from an aircraft to measure the strength of the blast wave from the atomic explosion, so as to allow the scientists to calculate the bomb's energy. He observed the [[Trinity (nuclear test)|Trinity nuclear test]] from a [[B-29 Superfortress]] that also carried fellow [[Project Alberta]] members [[Harold Agnew]] and [[Deak Parsons]].{{sfn|Alvarez|1987|pp=137–142}} Flying in the B-29 Superfortress ''[[The Great Artiste]]'' in formation with the ''[[Enola Gay]]'', Alvarez and Johnston measured the blast effect of the [[Little Boy]] bomb which was [[atomic bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki|dropped on Hiroshima]].{{sfn|Alvarez|1987|pp=6–8}} A few days later, again flying in ''The Great Artiste'', Johnston used the same equipment to measure the strength of the [[Nagasaki bomb|Nagasaki]] explosion.{{sfn|Alvarez|1987|pp=144–146}} He was the only person to witness the Trinity test and the bombings of both Hiroshima and Nagasaki. Johnston never regretted the part he had played in the bombings. Years later, Johnston recalled:{{quote| Back at Los Alamos there was lots of rejoicing. "We won the War!" But several important people were having pangs of conscience, most notably Oppenheimer. Yes we had stopped the wartime killing, but we had killed a lot of people with our bombs, and worst of all we had let the genie out of the bottle, and now nuclear war would be a specter for the world to face. … Oppie felt especially responsible for this nuclear worry, and he made public statements of remorse. I think it was because of this that Oppie was forgiven by the 1945 Peace Activists in the Physics community. Instead he became their hero. But Alvarez was not forgiven, and he suffered public insults as a warmonger. The same for Ernest Lawrence. The Peace activists sounded like they wished we had lost the war, or at least that it had ended in a bloody stalemate.{{cite web |url=http://blog.nuclearsecrecy.com/2011/12/06/r-i-p-paul-doty-and-lawrence-h-johnston/ |title=R.I.P.: Paul Doty and Lawrence H. Johnston |accessdate=August 31, 2013 }}}} ==After the war== After the war, Johnston returned to graduate school at Berkeley. Under Alvarez's supervision, he wrote his PhD thesis at the [[Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory]] on the "Development of the Alvarez-type proton linear accelerator". After he graduated in 1950, he became an associate professor at the [[University of Minnesota]]. There, he built a 68 MeV proton linear accelerator, which he used to perform proton-proton scattering experiments. In 1964, he joined the Physics Laboratory of [[The Aerospace Corporation]], where he learned techniques for investigating [[far infrared]] radiation. In 1964, Johnston moved to the [[Stanford Linear Accelerator Center]] as head of the Electronics Department. He worked there on the construction of a {{convert|2|mi|km|adj=mid|-long}}, 20 GeV electron linear accelerator. He became a professor of physics at the [[University of Idaho]] in 1967, and focused on nuclear physics, [[Far-infrared laser|far infrared lasers]], and [[Emission spectrum|molecular spectroscopy]]. Johnston retired in 1988 at age 70, and continued to reside in Moscow as professor emeritus until his death. In retirement, Johnston made a number of trips to Israel to work on biblical archaeology projects. He was a strong supporter of Christian ministries, and believed in [[intelligent design]]. Johnston died of [[lung cancer]] at age 93 in his home in Moscow on December 4, 2011. Married for 69 years, he was survived by his wife Millie and their five children. ==Honors== *[[Phi Beta Kappa]], 1939 *Elected Member, Society of the [[Sigma Xi]], 1950 *Elected Fellow, [[American Physical Society]], 1953 *Elected Fellow, [[American Scientific Affiliation]], about 1952 *Sigma Xi award, Outstanding Research Paper of the year, 1976 **Stark Spectrum of Methyl Alcohol in the Far Infrared with R. P. Srivastava. J. Mol. Spectroscopy 61 147 (1976). Source: ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==Bibliography== *{{cite book |author=Alvarez |first=L. revision.comment: +fix link
revision.text:
{{Essay|date=July 2009}} With the issue of supplying water to a very large population, the [[Ancient Rome|Romans]] developed hydraulic systems for multiple applications: public water supply, power using water mills, [[hydraulic mining]], fish tanks, irrigation, fire fighting, and of course [[Roman aqueduct|aqueduct]] (Stein 2004). Scientists such as [[Ctesibius]] and [[Archimedes]] produced the first inventions involving hydraulic power (Oleson 1984).
==Specific technology== The most prevalent hydraulic pump used in maritime situations in [[ancient Rome]] was the [[bilge pump]], which functioned to siphon collected water out of a ship’s hull (Oleson 1984). The bilge pump was an improvement on the first hydraulic pumps used in antiquity: force pumps. Invented around the early 3rd century BCE, the most primitive design of a force pump consisted of a piston pushing water out of a tube, constructed by soldering individual bronze elements (Stein 246).
Written accounts from Phil of Byzantium (late 3rd century BCE), Vitruvius (c. 25 BCE), and Hero of Alexandria (c. CE 50) confirm archaeological evidence for the original simple design, and both Hero and Vitruvius specify that the pump was typically made of bronze (Stein 2004). Somewhere along the way a new design arose that involved cutting apertures into an individual wood block and then rendering the block pressure-proof with tightly fitting plugs and plates (Stein 2004).
Although cheaper and easier to manufacture, assemble, and repair, the wooden pumps manufactured from then on would most likely not have been durable enough for maritime use, which is why we usually find lead pipes associated with bilge pumps, bilge wells, and hydraulic devices of other function about ships. The amphora shipwreck discovered at Grado in Gorizia, Italy, which dates to around 200 CE, and contained what archaeologists hypothesized to be a ‘hydraulics’ system to change the water in live fish tanks, since other evidence indicates the ship’s involvement in the processed fish trade (Beltrame and Gaddi 2005).
This hypothesis has been disputed, since the wooden box protecting a lead pipe along the longitudinal axis of the hull found on the wreck suggest the existence of a bilge well (Oleson and Stein 2007). Previous ships involved in live fish tank transport, entitled navis vivariae, did not employ a hydraulic system, and for this reason the hypothesis proves especially questionable (Boetto 124). For example, one of the wrecks found in Claudius’s harbor at the modern Fiumicino Airport in Italy was a small fish craft dating somewhere around the 2nd century CE. Archaeologists discovered a fish-well in the middle of the ship that used the hole/plump system bored in the bottom of the boat to fill the tank (Boetto 2006). Other than the Grado wreck no other evidence exists of hydraulic systems being used in the fish industry.
==References==
{{No footnotes|date=May 2009}} Beltrame, C. and Gaddi, D. 2005. “The Rigging and the “Hydraulic System” of the Roman wreck at Grado, Gorizzia, Italy,” The International Journal of Nautical Archaeology 34: 79-87.
Beltrame, C. and Gaddi, D. “Preliminary Analysis of the Hull of the Roman Ship from Grado, Gorizia, Italy,” IJNA36: 138-147.
Boetto, G. 2006. “Roman techniques for transport and conservation of fish. The case of the Fiumicino 5 wreck in the light of some ethnographic comparisons,” in L. Blue and F. Hocker (eds), Conducted by the Sea, X International Symposium on Boat and Ship Archaeology, Roskilde 2003.
Oleson, J. P. 1984. Greek and Roman Mechanical Water lifting Devices: the History of a Technology. Toronto: Toronto University Press.
Oleson, J. P. and Stein R. 2007. “Comment on a Recent Article Concerning the Hydraulic System of the Roman Wreck at Grado, Gorizia, Italy,” IJNA 35 (2): 415-417.
Stein, R. J. B. 2004. “Roman Wooden Force Pumps: A case study in innovation.” Journal of Roman Archaeology 17 221-50.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Maritime Hydraulics In Antiquity}} [[Category:Hydraulics]] [[Category:History of technology]] [[Category:Ancient Roman technology]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Masergy Communications | logo = Masergy logo.png | industry = [[Software]] | hq_location_city = [[Plano, Texas]] | hq_location_country = [[United States of America]] | revenue = US$300 million | revenue_year = 2016 | key_people = James Parker (CEO), Robert Bodnar (CFO)<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.masergy.com/about-us/management-team/|title= Meet Our Management Team|accessdate=August 18, 2017}}</ref> | num_employees = 500 | num_employees_year = 2015 | website = https://www.masergy.com }}
'''Masergy Communications''' ({{IPAc-en|ˌ|m|ə|ɪ|s|ɚ|ʤ|i|}}, {{respell|MAY|ser|JEE|}}) is a software defined networking services company founded in 2000 and headquartered in Plano, Texas. The company provides Secure Hybrid Networking, Managed Security, and Cloud Communications.<ref>{{cite web|title=Masergy Communications Is No. 4364 on the Inc. 5000|url=https://www.inc.com/profile/masergy-communications|website=Inc.com|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Big Data analytics benefits from high-performance network|website=Cloud Strategy Magazine|url=http://www.cloudstrategymag.com/articles/86336-big-data-analytics-benefits-from-high-performance-network|date=22 August 2016|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Moore|first1=John|title=Cybersecurity concerns fuel MSSPs, managed security market|url=http://searchitchannel.techtarget.com/feature/Cybersecurity-concerns-fuel-MSSPs-managed-security-market|website=TechTarget}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Shimel|first1=Alan|title=Masergy adds MSSP to its lineup|url=http://www.networkworld.com/article/2226830/opensource-subnet/masergy-adds-mssp-to-its-lineup.html|work=Network World|date=1 May 2014|language=en}}</ref>
Masergy's customers include Huisman<ref>{{cite web|last1=Seals|first1=Tara|title=Dutch Construction Giant Taps Masergy for Hybrid WAN|url=https://channelvisionmag.com/dutch-construction-giant-taps-masergy-sd-wan/|publisher=Channel Vision|accessdate=6 October 2017}}</ref>, Pattonair<ref>{{cite web|last1=Boulton|first1=Clint|title=SDN providers nibbling away at slow-moving MPLS carriers|url=https://www.cio.com/article/3093257/networking/sdn-providers-nibbling-away-at-slow-moving-mpls-carriers.html|publisher=CIO|accessdate=6 October 2017}}</ref>, PRGX, Inc.<ref>{{cite web|title=Big Data analytics benefits from high-performance network|url=https://www.cloudstrategymag.com/articles/86336-big-data-analytics-benefits-from-high-performance-network|website=Cloud Strategy|accessdate=6 October 2017}}</ref>, [[Eurostar]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=Santo|first1=Brian|title=Masergy Designs Hybrid WAN for European Train Service|url=https://www.sdxcentral.com/articles/news/masergy-designs-hybrid-wan-european-train-service/2017/04/|website=SDX Central|accessdate=6 October 2017}}</ref>, [[Dolby Laboratories]], and the [[Hallmark Channel]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Surviving a mid-stage crisis: Masergy disrupts the networking services industry when it grows up in a hurry|url=http://www.sbnonline.com/article/surviving-a-mid-stage-crisis-masergy-disrupts-the-networking-services-industry-when-it-grows-up-in-a-hurry/|publisher=Smart Business Network, Inc.|accessdate=6 October 2017}}</ref>
Masergy was acquired by [[Berkshire Partners]] in 2016 for an undisclosed amount, and had been previously acquired by [[ABRY Partners]] LLC, a private equity investment firm, for an undisclosed price.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Buckley|first1=Sean|title=Masergy sold to Berkshire Partners {{!}} FierceTelecom|url=http://www.fiercetelecom.com/telecom/masergy-gets-acquired-by-berkshire-partners|website=www.fiercetelecom.com|publisher=FierceTelecom|accessdate=19 August 2017|language=en|date=25 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Berkshire Partners nears deal to acquire Masergy: sources|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-masergy-m-a-berkshirepartners-idUSKCN12N0WJ|work=Reuters|date=2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Shinneman|first1=Shawn|title=Boston firm to acquire Plano-based Masergy for reported $900 million|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/dallas/news/2016/10/24/boston-firm-to-acquire-plano-based-masergy-for.html|publisher=Dallas Business Journal|date=24 October 2016}}</ref>
==Corporate structure== ===Acquisitions and subsidiaries=== Early on, Masergy was backed by venture investors. In 2003, Centennial Ventures and Meritage Funds jointly invested a total of $31 million in Masergy. And in 2005, WestAM led a group that invested $30 million in Masergy.<ref>{{cite web|title=Masergy Communications > Recent News & Activity|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/masergy-communications/timeline/timeline|publisher=Crunchbase|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref>
Chris MacFarland joined Masergy as its chief operating officer in 2008, and was named its CEO in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bounds|first1=Jeff|last2=Nielsen|first2=Karen|last3=Perez|first3=Christine|last4=Vosburgh|first4=Glenda|title=Entrepreneurs of the Year 2014|url=https://www.dmagazine.com/publications/d-ceo/2014/july-august/entrepreneurs-of-the-year-ey-2014/?single=1|publisher=D Magazine|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref> In August 2011, Masergy was acquired by ABRY Partners LLC, a private equity investment firm, for an undisclosed price.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Berndtson|first1=Chad|title=Masergy Acquired By ABRY Partners|url=http://www.crn.com/news/networking/231001033/masergy-acquired-by-abry-partners.htm|publisher=CRN|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref>
Masergy acquired Broadcore Communications for an undisclosed purchase price in July 2012. Broadcore offered communications services, including video calling and call recording, for businesses.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bounds|first1=Jeff|title=Masergy Communications buys Broadcore|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/dallas/news/2012/07/12/masergy-buys-broadcore.html|accessdate=31 August 2017}}</ref>
In April 2014, Masergy acquired Global DataGuard, broadening its portfolio to include managed security services for enterprise customers. Its Unified Enterprise Security solution includes advanced persistent threat management and adaptive network behavioral analysis.<ref>{{cite web|title=Masergy Acquires Global DataGuard|url=https://www.infosecurity-magazine.com/news/masergy-acquires-global-dataguard/|website=Info Security Group}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Kobialka|first1=Dan|title=Masergy Communications Acquires Global DataGuard|url=http://mspmentor.net/mergers-acquisitions/040814/masergy-communications-acquires-global-dataguard|website=MSPmentor|accessdate=31 August 2017}}</ref>
In September 2018, James Parker was named the new CEO.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.dmagazine.com/business-economy/2018/09/plano-based-masergy-communications-names-new-ceo/|title=Plano-Based Masergy Communications Names New CEO - D Magazine|date=2018-09-13|work=D Magazine|access-date=2018-09-25|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Services== Masergy delivers Secure Hybrid Networking, cybersecurity and cloud communications to global enterprises<ref>{{cite web|last1=Shinneman|first1=Shawn|title=The story of Masergy – from 2000 founding to 2016 acquisition – in the words of CEO Chris MacFarland|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/dallas/news/2017/01/24/the-story-of-masergy-from-2000-founding-to-2016.html|accessdate=13 December 2017}}</ref> for clients in industries such as manufacturing, healthcare, entertainment, finance, broadcasting, and more. The company provides voice, data, and video network services across the globe, specializing in Ethernet-based [[virtual private network|virtual private networks (VPNs)]] and [[wide area network|wide area networks (WANs)]], Masergy's cloud services include network and application management, global cloud communications, and hosted remote access. The company's managed services focus on disaster recovery and security.<ref>{{cite web|title=Masergy Communications, Inc. Revenue and Financial Data|url=http://www.hoovers.com/company-information/cs/revenue-financial.Masergy_Communications_Inc.ffbeabfd38967578.html|publisher=Dun & Bradstreet|accessdate=16 October 2017}}</ref>
In 2017, Masergy added a new option to its SD-WAN service called SD-WAN Go, which includes embedded firewalls, zero-touch provisioning from the Masergy portal, and WAN optimization.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Wilson|first1=Carol|title=Masergy Expands SD-WAN Options|url=http://www.lightreading.com/carrier-sdn/sd-wan/masergy-expands-sd-wan-options/d/d-id/733004|website=LightReading|accessdate=31 October 2017}}</ref>
==Awards==
May 2013: Masergy’s CEO, Chris MacFarland, was named a finalist in Ernst & Young’s Enterpreneur of the Year Southwest Area North.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ernst & Young’s Enterpreneur of the Year Southwest Area North|url=http://www.ey.com/US/en/Newsroom/News-releases/Ernst-and-Young-announces-Entrepreneur-Of-The-Year-2013-finalists-in-Southwest-Area-North-Awards-program|website=Ernst & Young}}</ref>
June 2015: Masergy’s CEO, Chris MacFarland, was awarded Ernst & Young’s Entrepreneur of the Year 2015 for the technology/telecom sector in the U.S. southwest.<ref>{{cite web|title=EY announces Entrepreneur Of The Year® 2015 Award recipients in the Southwest|url=http://www.ey.com/US/en/Newsroom/News-releases/news-ey-announces-entrepreneur-of-the-year-2015-award-recipients-in-the-southwest|website=Ernst & Young}}</ref>
2015: Masergy ranked #4180 on Inc. magazine’s Inc. 5000 list for 2015. The magazine cited Masergy’s 67 percent growth rate over three years. This also marked the fifth time Masergy was included on the Inc. 5000 list.<ref>{{cite web|title=Masergy Communications|url=http://www.inc.com/profile/masergy-communications|website=Inc. Magazine}}</ref>
2017: Masergy’s CEO, Chris MacFarland, was named as one of the top 10 highest rated CEOs on Glassdoor.<ref>{{cite web|title=Highest Rated CEOs - 2017 Employee's Choice|url=https://www.glassdoor.com/Award/Highest-Rated-CEOs-at-SMBs-LST_KQ0,26.htm|website=Glassdoor}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
